La historia es muy interesante, con una idea relativamente original y que sorprende desde el inicio. Impacta desde la primera escena y va al grano desde ese momento prácticamente, sin rodeos. La estructura de pequeños arcos unidos en el arco principal funciona perfectamente y la trama te mantiene en vilo de forma constante, incluso en el epílogo final.


Es posible que se eche en falta algo de más profundidad y globalidad a la hora de presentar el tema de la invasión de los parásitos y si conflicto con los humanos. No obstante hablamos de un problema a escala mundial por lo que nos dan a entender. Quizá con más capítulos o temporadas se podría haber desarrollado algo más esta idea. A cambio de eso tenemos una visión más cercana de Shinichi, el protagonista, cómo le afecta a él y a su entorno más próximo. Son dos formas diferentes de enfocarlo y diría que no se pueden considerar ni mejor ni peor, simplemente dos puntos de vista distintos.


Otro punto a destacar es que, salvo excepciones que se pudieran considerar más o menos lógicas, "Kiseijuu" no se corta un pelo en eliminar personajes con relativa importancia, tanto para el guión como para el propio protagonista. Y por supuesto, hablando de guión, el marcado mensaje pro-conservación de la tierra que tiene la historia, con una cantidad importante de diálogos y monólogos a lo largo de los capítulos defendiendo la naturaleza, el medio ambiente y sus criaturas, a la vez que se critica el poco respeto general de la humanidad por todo ello. Sin duda, una invitación a la reflexión sobre un tema que nos afecta y concierne a todos los habitantes de este planeta.


En cuanto a los personajes, creo que todos estaremos de acuerdo en que la estrella indiscutible es Migi, a pesar de no ser siquiera humano (sobre todo al inicio me recordaba en personalidad a Kyuubey de "Madoka Magica"). Shinichi es un buen protagonista, tiene una gran evolución a lo largo de la serie y cumple con creces con su labor. Ambos forman una pareja extraordinaria y copan la historia con una nota casi perfecta. En el gran debe de la serie, en mi opinión, están los personajes secundarios y su tratamiento. Pocos en cuanto a número y con un desarrollo prácticamente inexistente en su mayoría. A años luz del tándem Shinichi/Migi. Es cierto que hay personajes interesantes como Ryouko Tamiya o la denostada por muchos Satomi Murano, pero en general me queda la sensación de que se podría haber aprovechado mejor a los secundarios. Tenían posibilidades y material de sobra para hacerlo.


La música es una jodida maravilla. Tal cual. No hablo del opening (que es bueno, aunque diferente y arriesgado y eso no gusta a todo el mundo) ni del ending (correcto), sino especialmente de las melodías de fondo. Variadas, con ritmo, desde tonos electrónicos hasta armoniosos clásicos pasando por géneros tan poco oídos en el anime como el dubstep. Perfectamente sincronizadas con las escenas y elegidas de manera brillante para cada momento. En serio, melodías como I am, Bliss, Next to you, Kill the puppets o The truth son increíbles. De ésas que merecen ser oídas fuera del propio anime. Una genialidad de banda sonora.


"La tierra. Alguien tuvo un pensamiento repentino. La vida debe ser protegida."

Kiseijuu: Sei no Kakuritsu or Parasyte the maxim is one of those anime that constantly has you at the edge of your seat.
The show centers around parasitic alien life form coming to earth and taking over the bodies of humans by merging with their brains, kinda like invasion of the body snatchers. the show follows Sixteen-year-old high school student Shinichi Izumi who falls victim to one of these parasites, but it fails to take over his brain, ending up in his right hand instead.
The story and themes of this show have been told many times across film, cartoons and other anime however, Parasyte tells thestory of how mankind killing the earth and other life forms in a unique way that was enjoyable to watch. Main character Shinichi Izumi was handled pretty well in my opinion. I enjoyed his development throughout the show and how he changed from shy kid to total badass and I found him to be pretty relatable which is always a positive. The main parasite Migi was also pretty fun, I enjoyed the interactions between him and Schinichi and found their back and fourth throughout the show quite interesting. The supporting characters were also good although they lacked in the character department area some were still really great with the standout in my opinion being Reiko Tamura. The love interests Murano and Kana were decent but could have used more development in my opinion.


Madhouse studios once again do a fantastic job with the art and sound. The action sequences were absolutely phenomenal especially the fights between Shinichi and Goto.The voice acting was passable, none of the performances really stood out, but I think the actors did an incredible job.


Overall, I found Parasyte to be an incredible anime, I enjoyed the story, the comedy and the action sequences and loved the main character. The only problem I have with the show is that I would have liked to know more about the origins of the Parasites.

I haven't read the manga and will judge this anime on it's own merit.
I'm going over some points that I think are important for me.
1. Music: I feel the music was pretty good but they overused in particular two songs, one I think is an original and then one piece by Chopin, this probably become annoying when you binge-watch it as I did.
2. Visuals: Visuals were okay, some bakground shots were very annoyingly animated, it's one of those almost auto-generated idle-human very animated memes. Not very pleasant but overall I feel it was pretty okay.
3. Story: Interesting and altough it's not deep philosophy it's interesting.There are other series that handle this in a more meaningful way I think, like Monster. But it's pretty damn entertaining with a good climax. \n\n
4. Characters: This is were this shines through, even though there are some disposable bi-characters that are a little odd the main character and Migi (his parasite) are very well written. This non-emotion relation is very interesting for me and this anime really knew how to play on that strenght. I feel the "main" female character could have more development however.\n\n
5. Conclution: Good anime, entertaining and bring some concepts that makes you think. A little overfocus on the envoirment which felt a little odd, beacuse this anime isn't at all about the envoirment except in two places were it's extremely "central" to the story. However I recommend this anime, especially with the over-saturated waifu shit that's out there.

Parasyte, you never know when to let up.
Coming back to this one a year later and I must admit, it's better the second time around. Parasyte is about a young man named Shinichi Izumi who is one of many to get infected by an unknown origin from what we later figure out is a Parasyte who he respectably calls 'Migi.' The two of them at first seem very distant, but in time grow into a cool, sentimental bond that only they can understand. It's a formidable tale of two organisms living in tandem.
I have a strange liking toward the OP, it's catchy, yet just doesn'tquite make too much sense. As for the Art-style, it's beautiful, but with a nasty catch. I love everything it does right, with the intense action scenes of two parasytes fighting. But I cannot stand the weird "3D" animation that they sometimes throw into the mix of regular anime-looking things. That entire prospect ruins the art-style for me.


It does however get better with the characters. Migi is the most interesting here, while at first he doesn't seem to quite understand just what being "human" is, but he slowly starts developing a sense of right for himself. Shinichi is what you would call a 180. He starts out as a gentle, kind high school boy who wears glasses and is very sensitive, but soon follows a path that most other in his shoes would want nothing to do with. Shinichi over time develops a sense of being able to control himself to uppermost limits, and for good reason. While his classmates and his father try to crack the code the shinichi has made far too apparent. As for the classmates and shinichi's father, they are all respectable characters that may not get too much screen time, but the time we see them, it's all good fun.


I must admit, this show always brings the unexpected. One moment could lead to something unthinkable in the next, and I like that about this one. This is a great watch and I highly recommend this. This was my second watch and like I said before, It DOES get better the more you watch.

This is one of the few seinen anime in recent years that has been universally praised by fans and critics alike; some people have criticized it for being rated higher than how it should be rated. In my honest opinion, I think that Kiseijuu is a decent seinen anime. There's definitely something about it that intrigues me. 
As you've heard before from the synopsis of this anime (if you actually did read the synopsis), Kiseijuu tells the story of strange small parasites who take over a human's body and mind. In this anime, the story is based off of Izumi Shinichi, who is an averagehigh school student. He is unlike any of his other fellow humans because he has a creature on his right hand. That creature is known as Migi, who is one of the parasites that exists on earth. Unlike Migi's fellow parasites, he (it's a male) has failed to take over Shinichi's mind, so Migi instead takes over Shinichi's right hand. These parasites or creatures are what a normal human would expect them to be. They are heartless, and their only goal is to survive in a world where humans have dominated the entire population. To achieve this goal, they resort to becoming a human themselves by taking over a human completely.


Typical of a seinen anime, Kiseijuu has a lot of bloody gore that is not to be viewed by people with weak stomachs. Anyways, as simple as the premise may be, the story itself is rather decent. It is a rather serious anime with some emotional and gut-wrenching moments. If you were to ask me, I would say that an anime with a rather simple story but with good execution can definitely be a decent series indeed and Kiseijuu does just that. Also, Kiseijuu does not really have a "main plot" because it is character-driven. Most of the anime is not just about Shinichi being forced to live with a creature on his right hand but rather, the characters involved around him.


Because of the fact that this show is mostly character-driven, we were also able to get some very decent character development. For example, a parasite such as Ryoko Tamiya was once a creature who would basically only live to survive as she didn't really care much about humans. As the series progresses however, she begins to develop human-like traits such as laughing, smiling, and she even develops an affection for them. This trait also applies to other parasites as well because some of them, other than Ryoko,  begin to develop human traits which sets them apart from their other fellow creatures. Another example of some excellent character development is when Migi, who starts off as an emotionless being who only protects itself along with its host, ends up being much like Ryoko and even gains some affection towards Shinchi along with the humans near the end of the series. On the other hand, Shinichi becomes the complete opposite, and ends up becoming more and more like the parasites who have populated earth.


Other than Shinichi and the parasites, there were also some humans that have appeared in the show. Most of the humans in this show don't get as much development as the parasites but then again, they all do show some development as characters regardless. It was also somewhat strange, but some of the humans had a special trait that allowed to them to distinguish a human from a parasite. The characters who were capable of doing this were Kana, who has a crush on Shinichi, and Uragami, who is an imprisoned criminal. There are also antagonists that exist in Kiseijuu, and if you didn't already know, they are all parasites (not really a spoiler). 


The art and animation is nothing amazing; however, for an anime adaptation, the art/animation was rather impressive. The anime itself is an adaptation of the manga from the 1990's and because of the fact that Kiseijuu was made in 2014, the art was updated to look more modern. The blood and the gore looked pretty damn realistic too because I kinda got sick from watching people die. Anyways, despite being animated by Madhouse, I don't think the animation was great, but I know for a fact that it looked better than the manga. The sound on the other hand was definitely great. The OST in Kiseijuu was filled with a lot of dubstep music, some of which I thought were very decent, and for an anime with some dubstep music and whatnot, I think the soundtrack had fit the anime perfectly considering how it was a seinen. The opening is awesome as I think that it perfectly fits the anime. The ending was soft because it was sung by someone with a high voice, but I think that it was also pretty decent. All in all, the sound was definitely something that I liked.


In conclusion, I enjoyed the crap out of this anime. I liked its characters, its soundtrack, and I was definitely a fan of the story even if it wasn't anything magnificent. I did not really have any problems with this show because I couldn't really find anything wrong about it that was worth mentioning. This is an anime that I could easily recommend to anyone who is looking for a seinen that they could enjoy.

BONUS GRATUITOUS PRAISING!  An excellent sub AND a remarkable dub; you cant go wrong either way with this one.  Pick your pleasure.
                  The sci-fi gore types never really jump out at me so shows like parasyte rarely make it onto my plan to watch list.   My disdain for gore acted as a damn against a flood of mixed peer reviews ranging from , "ITS THE GREATEST"  all the way to "Overrated science fiction trashime, lol".     I finally ended up bored enough to give it a watch...  and I binged it in two nights.  



          Parasyte is a psychological horror type science fiction anime that is laced with philosophical viewpoints.  The psychological aspects of the story are generated form being presented complete situations that impact the protagonist and onlookers in big ways.  It's all in the open, and they never try to deceive the viewer.  This impressed me on a grand scale because the show is  themed around creatures that are masters of deception. 

          Viewers get the privilege to experience a dark set of emotions as the story develops. There is loss, hopelessness, helplessness, isolation,  and all these tragedian plot markers create the perfect garden of imperfection to watch the characters grow in.  Parasite is one hell of a ride.



                    The art is nothing to write home about, but it isn't sub par either.   I would call it average but it was used in amazing ways. There was a lot of location recycling but the characters change enough to give the anime a pass on that.  The action sequences were very well animated and the moods were set very perfectly.   So the look was bleh, but awesomely so,  just in case my contradictory justifications weren't connecting.   



               Parasite was a great show in the Sub and English dub formats.   That almost never happens.  Kudos to all sound studios and voice actors involved.  The world needs more good dubs.   The soundtrack itself was a little forced and obvious about trying to create the feels, but the enveloped content was not distorted by the agro emotion tracks.



                  Excellently written main cast of characters... for the show.  The protagonists were executed perfectly,  and the supporting cast played their positions of observation well, but you never feel like you get to know any of them.  I would have liked a little more backstory on everyone involved,  but the lack of character foundation makes it less ABOUT THEM, and more about the moments they are in.   I feel that was intended, and cant give the show poor marks over my personal desire to have a little more content.



            Parasyte,  I enjoyed the hell out of it, and wouldn't consider it a waste of anyone's time if they tossed it onto their plan to watch list. Grizzziff Kingsbeard gives Parasyte an uninfected [8/10].   If I  randomly change that score to [10/10]...   trust no one.

Parasyte is another big name anime that a lot of anime fans have heard of. It's a very unique story about evolution, co-existing, and is a bit philosophical. Let's just jump straight into this long-overdue review!
Story: 9
The story is very unique like I mentioned, and it is really cool! There are some really cool concepts, and I can't think of any plot holes. They definitely do a great job walking you through the story, and they also leave some things a mystery, but I like that. Essentially, the main character Shinichi has to cope with the fact that there's a parasite / alien in hishand, which lead to some really unique character development.


Art: 9


The art style is really nice and the animation looked good, too. However, it should be no surprise that I've seen better! Anyway, I give the art a 9, and I don't have much to say about it other than it looks nice, and fits with the story.


Sound: 10


Yes, yes, YES!!! In my opinion, the soundtrack is the best part of this anime. It has one of my favorite soundtracks in any anime, really. It's really interesting, and may be surprising, that a lot / most of the soundtrack is dubstep / techno. But keep in mind that it's very good quality! The soundtrack really makes the fight scenes a LOT cooler! I like how there are also themes that are quirky and comical. I think that really adds to the anime, too. I really can't explain the soundtrack. You just have to give it a listen yourself! There are even quite a few emotional pieces. I recall there also being a famous classical piece in the anime, which I found was a good touch, as long as it's not overused (it wasn't)!


Character: 9


Shinichi Izumi and Migi are arguably the best characters in the show. There are some pretty awesome villains, too, but keep in mind that there arcs are quite short unfortunately! But even though the anime is quite short, there was quite a lot of character development for not only our lovable main characters, but also the villains, too. The side characters were also pretty good. You may feel quite sad for some of the characters in this anime, too, which is really good!


Enjoyment: 9


This is a very fun anime that is REALLY damn funny. There were moments that caused me to laugh my ass off. In addition, with all of the great fight scenes, Parasyte proves to be difficult not to love. It's definitely a great anime that is worth your while to check out!


Overall: 9


9 is a really good score! It just didn't quite get to the point where I would consider it a 10, but that's okay! I can't just give out 10s to EVERY anime that I love. It just wouldn't make sense. I feel like a lot of people give this anime a 9, and I honestly feel like that's what it deserves. So, Parasyte, thanks for being awesome!

I'm not a big fan of inhuman creatures, mostly because they usually play a role where they lack sympathy for other creatures.
Parasyte gave me a different point of view, and a good one at that.
I often glance over images of anime series, in case I have checked them out before. 
This anime is no different at that, and oddly enough I always tried to look away when images popped up from this anime. 
Mostly because I thought most of the images were gross looking. 
But suddenly I got curious when I again, stumbled upon the Parasyte anime and then decided to try watching the firstepisode. 

Instantly, I was drawn to the anime. Mostly because I had a need of watching something new and perhaps a bit different from what I'm used to.


I really like it when an episode ends with a twist and gives me the reactions: "oh my god" or "whaaaat?"

Each and every episode in Parasyte ends like this. 


What really caught my attention was how the two main characters went through some intense development. Speaking of their personalities and their way of handling a difficult situation.


Getting used to all the gore and gross looking creatures didn't take as long as I thought it would, in fact, it took two episodes before I got used to it. 

That's a relief from my side. 


One thing that I really would like to point out is the details on the anime characters faces as they change. 

If there is a person that has a problem with taking care of themselves and ends up drinking and similar things, their faces will be turning pale and they will be looking older than what they actually are.

That's realistic of course and it's indeed an awesome detail to add. 



I enjoyed watching how the main characters trust in each other started to change.

In fact, they didn't trust each other at all in the beginning. I even started to think that things would never really change for the two of them.


Back to what I wrote at the top of the review, about how my point of view changed, regarding the unknown species, a parasyte in this case. 


Through the first episodes, we were given the impression that the parasytes are brutal creatures that does nothing but kill humans without any second thought. 

All of the parasytes I got to see were like this. 

They are fast learners though. The main character quickly learned how to communicate with the human it had tried to take over at first. It learned how to communicate in words within one single night. 

Well, I don't know if they at some point had their own personality but the main character was emotionless but a curious one. When it came up with a bunch of strategies it impressed me once again. 


As these parasytes started evolving and changing into a different direction than what I thought possible, they all became confused.

They started asking themselves: What are we? Why are we here?

"We eat meat in order to survive and so do you humans. In the end, it's all just instincts that tells us how to survive." 


Anything out of the ordinary has always frightened mankind. No, not just mankind but every specie we know of. 

These Parasytes that were slowly popping up everywhere around humans, became rather curious on what purpose each creature has on this planet. 

Some of them started observing humans rather than attacking them on sight.


"We humans protect other species because we feel alone. We protect the environment because we don't wanna go extinct. Look inside the human heart and all you'll find is self preservation"


I'm glad I watched the anime, I feel like the moral contains so much truth to it and it reminded me of how mysterious everything in the universe is.

How much we need to explore, and how much we won't ever be able to reach. 


9/10

Disappointing. The anime adaption does not live up to the manga, and it fails to communicate with color and sound what the original artist could do easily in black and white. Very, very many characteristic scenes were deleted in the anime, probably because the director thought they "weren't important", but those small scenes were necessary for character development. 
One of my biggest disappointments was how the anime failed to express the "animalistic glare" that we saw so clearly in the manga. This really shouldn't have been that hard to do, especially since we know very well what is possible in the anime adaption world. Asa comparison, I felt that the Made in Abyss anime adaption was much more powerful and expressive than the manga, whereas for Kiseijuu, it is clearly the reverse. 


I did enjoy the music quite a bit, except for the songs that were too dubsteppy.


I also felt that the character designs were quite strange and generic, especially for the female protagonist, although I suppose the same could be said for the original manga's characters, who are also quite generic in appearance. I am NOT a fan of how they added glasses to the main character, who didn't have them in the manga. Glasses are a powerful symbolic device for describing how someone "fails to see" or "cannot see clearly", and they seem to interfere with the director's already poor ability to express the power of the "animalistic gaze".


I give the show a 7/10 purely because the colorful animation does bring some unique quality compared to the manga, but it's still a disappointment. It could easily have done better if a more artistically-inclined director, like Yuasa Masaki, had done it. Without the character development, the show becomes more like a generic sci-fi thriller compared to the power of the manga's story.

~Pre-Review Thoughts~
Kiseijuu: Sei no Kakuritsu, was on my watch-list for a very long time, too long in fact. The title-card turned me off after I had watched a few gory shows with very to little plot or character development. Why do I always make this mistake with title-cards, maybe I'm too quick to judge? Who knows, but what I do know is I should have started watching this show as soon as I saw it, I shouldn't of gone 'plan to watch' I should've smashed 'watching' and dived right in.
Kiseijuu is a wonderful cesspool of questioning your own moral ethics, asking what it's like tobe human, understanding individuality, and grasping the concept of death. 


~Story~ 9/10


Shinichi Izumi has fallen victim to an alien that has attempted to burrow its way into his brain whilst he is sleeping one night. However, the alien fails and ends up burrowed in Shinichi's right hand/arm instead. While being fully sentient the alien which is now deemed Migi, (ironically dubbed 'right') doesn't quite understand the value of life, but rather holds a more evolutionary stance on ethical reasoning. Migi does not have to take over Shinichi's brain for he can feed off of him as a host without controlling his brain. However if Shinichi tells anyone about Migi, Migi will threaten to kill whom Shinichi tells for Migi does not want to become an 'experiment'. A pact is formed between the two to work together, mainly whenever one of Migi's 'kind' is close a fight will ensue. Later on in the show a deeper pact is formed between the two, a deeper plot is developed, and a deeper sense of fear is provoked. By the end of the show you will feel engaged and impacted by the stories' narrative.


~Art~ 10/10

When I think of connection in anime the first thing that comes to my mind is facial expression. The connectivity or the disconnect is seen here extraordinarily with these characters. It could possibly a facet that connects the primal instinct of the antagonists to our protagonist. Also this opening, oh my god. I'll get to that more in the next portion.

Oh yea and seeing people morph into scissor-like aliens and munch away at each other is pretty rad too. 


~Sound~ 10/10

Regarding the latter, (OP) it was stunning. The Soundtrack for the OP: Fear and loathing in las vegas - Let me hear, was stellar, upbeat and matched the OP's animation themes. It seems like whatever anime Fear and Loathing touch amazingly adds a little pixie-dust to the final product. Although the majority of the song is in English, (some would say broken English) the song describes the show and the OP itself reflects events to come.

Such tracks as Close To You get you emotionally involved within the situation, the fight tracks are a mechanical dubstep which plunges you into a fast paced fighting scene. Ken Arai did a magnificent job on this soundtrack.


~Character~ 8/10

Character development plays a major role in this show, mainly due to the fact of the main character is  drastically changing and effecting the lives of those around him. No stone is un-turned, even the antagonists at points in the show have a major development shift due to the psychological traits that the show provokes. If you came here for mindless violence you came to the wrong place.


~Enjoyment~ 10/10

Kiseijuu: Sei no Kakuritsu is a psychological thriller filled with gold nuggets. You're a miner, you came here for some gold, go watch it now and collect some.

Kiseijuu is worth your time and worth your purchase, and great show to watch with friends. 

You'l be on the edge of your seat, grabbing the tissue-box and wishing more existed after the show ends.

Parasyte...
is an interesting show, a good concept in paper but honestly this is one of the worst series I have ever seen. I will give my points on why this series is so dreadful to watch and describe some story bits here and there so yeah expect spoilers because they need to be told for some parts.
Story = 3
The story starts very simple, you have this ordinary and normal world, no magic, no superpowers, nothing out of the ordinary when suddenly these creatures from outerspace looking blobs show up and start invading living beings bodies ,from Humans to dogs. When we meet our main characterShinichi which is infected by one of them, so he tries to understand this fusion within his body and try to live a normal life  but also understand this blob looking thing which they agree to call Migi. 


The story starts very simple, trying to keep going in life and not make such a fuss about this invasion of new creatures, but the fusion Migi tried to do with  Shinichi fails because he could not reach his brain and now lives as part of his right arm. At first the story explains how these creatures survive by killing humans and killing other parasytes alike among other things that incllude when they decide to attack and some of their natural instincts they have. After the introduction is explained then the story makes a big 180 with a plot of revenge against these creatures because Shinichi loses someone important in his life because another parasytes kills that person. So he decides to protect and defend humanity against them and also exterminate every single one of them. Continuing with that then it is obvious that these creatures showing up and leaving death bodies in every corner around gets attention from the government and then we go with this philosophical cliche dilemmas if parasytes are good or bad beings, and why humanity is bad because they are the destroyers of everything surround him to later end that parasytes adapted and now live within the humans that they killed using their bodies as the human they are possessing 


This show's story in simple words doesn't know what it wants to be, they throw these ideas out of the blue just because reasons. The actions that drive the story are so poorly done, the dialogue is sometimes very lame, the actions and the characters are very idiotic to drive the story. But more of that later, because that's what affects the story more. Also the story tries way too hard to play with your feelings in such cheap and crappy way. Because again the characters that die in this show are so low on energy and simply not memorable at all except for the first death that is related to Shinichi. Also also this show throws super powers out of the nowhere because reasons. They establish that the setting is a normal and mundane world and only parasytes grant you super abilities but for some reason we have characters that become clairvoyants because.... yes again reasons and nothing is explained on how those super powers exist. 


Character = 2


If there are no characters there is no story but honestly I could not find characters at all except for 2, the main protagonists Shinichi and Migi.


Migi is the best out of both, because it shows how it is very antihuman in nature like not understanding human feelings, reasons and emotional drives everyone has. Also with a mentality of surviving no matter what and  in mind that he has to cooperate with Shinichi to achieve that. Migi does the job done of being the creature that wants to understand the human society but that fails to comprehend at all seeing that as waste of time even as something as basic of having a name. It is just that but is so well portraited that you get to understand and care for the hanging arm.


Shinichi is also very well portraited, he is afraid of all this chaos and rampage that is invading his life and the others. But with Migi being part of him he loses the sense of being human and goes in a very cold tone in many ways but also trying to not lose his soul and heart. 


These 2 are very basic characters but the actions and relations they have to just keep living complements each other and actually make a good pair that transform them into one solid character if you can say that because share the same body but for the rest.. hoo boy I have a lot to say.


First Murano is one of the dumbest and ridiculous characters I have ever seen, she is in constantly in love with Shinichi but starts to notice that he has changed but she still talks to him and tries to hit him and make him notice her. But when she talks to him and sees some of his actions she gets sad for seeing the drastic changes Shunichi has, but when she tries to accept him and sees that he is good in nature, she accepts him until another wrong action happens with him and we go into a infinite loop of "I love you but you changed, but I accept you, but I hate you because you change". Can this girl decide if he is good or not jeez? the unnecessary whining is so idiotic. Also she is a big airhead because along the story there is a part where Shinichi saves her by him falling with HER from like a 10 floor bulding and then him jumping through a barricade of like 4 meters and believe he was drived by the moment. I mean what kind of stupidity you have to be believing that a normal human can do that. Again this is a normal and mundane, no magic nothing like that at all setting, so no human is possible to do that simply 0% at all and to believe that it's because of the adrenaline rushing through your body is simply lazy, playing and making a fool out of the users watching. There is no characteristic besides that from her, she is useless and doesn't add anything to the series except of Shinichi wanting to protect her from the parasytes.


Then we have Kana, oh another useless character, she for some reasons has wet dreams with Shinichi, after she being part of thugs that assault Shinichi and touches him, she gets this superpower of sensing parasytes. Then with her it is just that wet dream, meeting with shinichi and use of her power, repeat the loop. It is not explained at all how this power came to be, it is just there because............. yeah again no explanation. She uses this power to attract Shinichi but for what? Just to get killed because the dumbass doesn't know that it makes her sense other human eating parasytes around the area. So knowing that she just risks her life like an idiot just to see if her wet dream of Shinichi and her making babies comes true and it is just that. She doesn't serve another purpose than being another person Shinichi must protect. This character could be cut from the show and you don't miss anything at all.


Then the human population as a whole is simply more retarded. There is one episode when a parasyte invades the school Murano and Shinichi go and shows that is a threat and danger to everyone around. Later they have a parasyte camouflage as a student and after getting poisoned and can't return to a human form,then it starts attacking everyone that is around it, just to show the students happily joking and KNOWING the threat like that  already happened and that killing teachers and other students is not a big deal. But for some reason this is lovely goofy trick and prank of some sorts to them when it is clearly that is not something like that. Yeah I will be laughing my ass knowing that my life is in danger after hearing many news of brutal deaths of local citizens around my city. So normal right???


Also when the government gets the inside of what these creatures are and tell the population on how to detect them, noboby questions how to protect yourself from them in such case to say at least, when they report that the parasyte that they found and made test on him that he killed students, teachers and police reinforcements during the moment they tried to stop it. What they say is that they have to pull part of your hair and if some cells are moving after doing it they demostrate that they are parasyte and you defend with nothing, because you are already dead. Honestly is this society so stupid to don't question things like that? The show just go and roll with it because again reasons unknown. So yeah the government is horrendous at this but also the citizens not questioning nothing at all contribute to this idiotic way of life.


Finally the other parasytes, they are simply bland. The only ones that have some traits are Ryouko and Parasite. Ryouko with its understanding more about the humans, like doing sexual acts and raising a child as it is in a woman body but just that. Parasite would have been a great character to add with the dilemma of parasites adapting to its human partner and not controlling him/her completely but it is wasted because Shinichi and his owner Uda are the only ones that achieve this cooperation. The rest of the parasytes in the show are your typical villain of the week showing up and trying to devour everything in their path, even the last parasyte form called Gotou is just that, a multiple parasytes body created by Ryouko just to see how it goes with this social experiment until they die. Nothing more than that.


Sound = 5


The sound is a mixed bag. Some tunes are great some are just meh. The main ones being Next to You and Speak. But the Dubstep included in fight scenes is so out of place. They just throw it to put an ost there and I like dubstep music but it is just inserted because the scene needs music but it doesn't have something good to it, when they changed to the more instrumental and dramatic tunes for the fight scenes it got better. The opening and ending for me feel out of place. The opening is just your typical screamo autotune edge song that is required in your show if it has some gore in it and the ending is like meh, the song is not bad but it feels out of place when you see a head being cut from its body and tons of blood to this relaxed song coming up, it feels weird. The transition that they do is so sudden after a brutal scene happened. The voice actors do a great job, they portrait the characters really good even when some are just lifeless characters in the show but they bring out the little heart and soul they have,


Art=9


Simply outstanding. The character design is so well done. There aren't any weird frames when you pause an episode, the highspeed of the parasytes attacking each other is fabulous and exciting to watch. Everything is so fluid in this show and so amazing to watch and appreciate. The only thing I would criticize is the CGI in large crowds. Holy cow this tendency keeps going. They just look weird and like those early 3D videogames attempts but with HD resolution. They look bad honestly but other than that the production Madhouse did simply surpasses a lot other shows that  do animate even to this day (2019)


Enjoyment = 3


Many things bugged me with this show. So many inconsistent things going with the story, the changed of the plot is horrible and the crappy superpower without explanation was tough to watch without questioning every single time. I couldn't entertain myself with this besides the battles and the AMV I did for this thing. 


Overall = 2


This show is simply dumb, they treat the spectator as an idiot with their crappy plot points and inconsistent direction. Besides the battles and wanting to find how will end, I don't see the appeal of this, it is so basic but the basicness of it lacks a lot of elements that could be improved even if is adapted from an 80s manga and change the setting to this 2010s world, 


Well thanks for reading this review. Enjoy whatever you are doing and see you around this site. Take care.

This anime is as bad as it is overrated, I watched all 24 episodes, and frankly I admit it was good for a little while but things got rotten when the anime hit the second half.
They call it a horror anime and one of the best anime in recent memory, I found it to be quite repetitive and lacking in anything good. The animation was pretty top notch but the characters, theme, and story were incredibly shitty and the protagonist is a bad toady version of Shinji Ikari who doesn't really change and and he keeps melting into poop because I have lost all respectfor this anime.


They try to make the series interesting by adding themes of Environmentalism, survival, Human condition, and the complexity of morality but the painful truth is that people of the current generation overanylse everything and try to get all philosophical and shit but the anime itself is nothing but stylized action and cheap jump scares and the audience is high on weed trying to cope with the utter faliure of this anime.


The characters fail miserably to intrigue me, most of them are bland and uncolorful and the protagonist doesn't have any real character development apart from changing into a mopey whining pathetic crappy hero who is as interesting as a log of wood in the toilet. He just helps people, that all he does, he is a cliched reluctant superhero who doesn't bother to help himself, even if it turns him into an asshole. That's not my kind of hero.


Reiko Tamura, one of the villains was kinda of okay but after her so called heartbreaking death and how she learned about the value of human life really pissed me off. You think you can just redeem yourself by dying, even though you murdered dozens of people and terroized an entire nation, and then release an mass murdering super parasite on the people, no freakin way, she went the coward's way out and she gets no sympathy from me. She's a horrorible self serving asshole bitch who deserved an painful death with no restraints. 


In my final paragraph, perhaps one of the worst parts of this anime is the emtional scenes, its overused and overhyped nowadays and everybody wants to cry all the time. I'm not saying that stuff is bad but when you overuse it to tighten the emtional quality, it's gets ridicious and overbearing. One of the most underhanded methods is when they try to make you cry, not just because of the intellectual factor but just to make something that's clearly sad and make you ball your eyes out. It's repugent and stupid and I find it's commonly used these days to bolster the ratings of the networks that air these shows. 

You can trick my eyes into crying but my Brain knows what your really doing and your damn lucky, I won't book a flight to Japan and kick your arrogant hippy asses.


I'm out.

Parasyte is an amazing action/drama packed with super gory action, from start to finish. Even though it is mostly action, there are some touching moments that pull on the heartstrings. 
It was a very realistic and reasonable reaction to what would happen if aliens came to earth. 
Also handles topics such as "what makes a human, human? ", "What is love, and how does it affect the way that we and act?", " humans are destroying the earth by themselves, would it really be better off if these aliens wiped the entire population out?" " humans exhibit altruistic behavior, even though it is entirelyirrational. Why is that?" \n\n
Overall, spectacular show

Parasyte to me is the most disappointing anime of all time. The first five episodes showed how Shinichi really had to learn to grow with Migi and show him how they have to be civil about how they take care of people and deal with their problems. But at the end of episode 5 when Shinichi's mom comes home from vacation and Migi heals him, this show becomes insufferable for the next six episodes with only one redeeming character, being Kana. After Kana's story is wrapped up over the next few episodes and the story with Ryouko is resolved not long after, which are actuallygood story lines instead of episodes 6-11, the show becomes very solid from episodes 19-21 with the city hall raid. But the last few episodes in the forest are overly convoluted and create and unnecessary plot point and character that drags out the story for longer, but in episode 23 my biggest problem with the show is temporarily resolved, which is Shinichi acting like an actual human. before I go more into why I was disappointed by this show, let me talk about what I liked. The op was fantastic and really got me through the bad episodes, the first 5 episodes were perfection, and the art style was pretty good as well. The two main character deaths are full of emotion and accompanied by a fantastic OST that brought tears to my eyes, and the action was pretty enjoyable at times and the city hall raid was enjoyable. Now with why I'm typing this out in the first place, why I think its not very good. Episode 6 completely took Shinichi form one of the best MC's of all time to worse than your average Kirito type character that has no personality. This is made worse because he had a lot of personality, but it was all taken away for some mindless violence and being "cool and edgy" for no reason. Now lets compare this to the protagonist of my favorite manga, Kaneki from Tokyo Ghoul. These two series are compared a lot, and I see why, with the similar premise they both have and main character that goes through trauma and becomes stone cold. Kaneki, as a character, is very complex and has a motivation to protect everyone so he doesn't lose anyone again, like what happened to Ryoko, this plus the torture he got is the reason why he changed and became the way he is. Shinichi, on the other hand, takes a fatal injury and Migi has to repair him and get his cells in Shinichi's brain and that's why he changes. these two differences are exactly why Tokyo Ghoul is great to me, but Parasyte is just okay. The reason I say episodes 6-11 suck are because Shinichi doesn't feel relatable at all or able to project myself on to him at all. This is the main reason I dislike Parasyte and if Shinichi had never changed, the show could've been a 9 or 10 to me.

There's not much to say really.
I loved this series. The soundtrack was magnificent, the characters were lovable, the story was well structured, the fight scenes were thrilling and the series was very unpredictable.
Parasyte is really good at turning the most simplest of scenes into heart retching moments. 
The series greatly resembled Tokyo Ghoul but still kept to its own theme and story at the same time.
As I said before the soundtrack is unforgettable and leaves me speechless.
I loved the concept of having a talking hand as a friend fighting through endless battles.
This series similarly to Re Zero looks at the psychological stages and moral choiceson who's right and wrong, humans or Parasyte's which was very interesting to follow.\n\n
Overall I gave this series a 10/10 and it definitely deserves it.

I normally don’t go for serious genres or anything “horror” and decided to try this out, I was very pleasantly surprised at how much I enjoyed this. It was a bit of a slow start with some characters I didn’t like at first, but it got real good and remained that way up until the very end. This was the most fun I’ve had watching anime in quite some time!
TL;DR: A really good show with lots of blood and really good at creating suspense. 
(Spoiler free review from an anime-only watcher’s perspective)
STORY:
9/10
Cool ideas and execution, I like that it was never explained super in-depth forthe most part and kept an air of mystery which I think worked really well at keeping you engaged and interested in what was going to happen next. I didn’t find anything very predictable and definitely gasped out loud a number of times while watching, not being sure what the outcome was going to be for a number of dramatic scenes.


ART:

9/10

Looked very good overall. Some lazy scenes and characters becoming very blob-like(and not just the parasytes) when there were wide or distance shots, but I’m finding as I watch more anime that it’s almost to be expected for budget/time saving I guess. The parasytes sure did look freaky when they were first introduced and pretty solidly threatening throughout the series. 

I feel like they almost could have gone more intense with the gore but I’m probably glad they didn’t as I’m the type who would probably get squeamish easily, I almost stopped watching immediately after starting the anime and seeing the very intense first scene, but I’m really glad I kept going.

Just the scenes were very dark in a few of them, with the colours being hard to distinguish the subject but that’s probably like why people dint want to see Batman in broad daylight, it ruins the mystery and literally lightens the mood too much, so I can’t really complain.

Overall, really well done and suited the tone.


SOUND:

10/10

Good OP, I love how it turns to what sounds to me like screaming and pure angst, really good for getting me hyped for the episode. 

The ending was a nice contrast, being so peaceful, almost felt like tearing up several times. 

One thing that was also a really nice touch for me was the music that would play for the preview shots of the next episode, it was really eerie and always freaked me out.


CHARACTER:

9/10


Okay so the main character I found pretty unlikeable at first, but his actions were always somewhat realistic(although a huge wimp at first) but it made his later actions so much more justifiable and satisfying to see. I loved seeing the character growth and interactions. Even the characters that I felt didn’t get fleshed out much or development were still mostly realistic, if a bit dull at times.

Overall, no huge relying on stereotypical character tropes like the super tsundere etc which was a nice change to see.

I liked how human (or in the non-human cases how non-human) their choices and actions felt.


ENJOYMENT:

10/10


Was not expecting to enjoy this this as much as I did. This was fun, it grabbed me in and although I was a bit skeptical at first, had me looking forward to each next episode I watched. There were a good number of cliffhangers, but also some surprising nice episode ends so I never felt like the anime was trying to be cheap with fake outs and the like.


OVERALL:

10/10


Very fun alien spooky anime drama. Had good drama and mystery and actual good characters that I enjoyed seeing progress and mess up.

Shinchi and Migi are forever best bros to me, this made me think of the 2018 Venom movie, this was almost like a buddy-cop at times which only added to the fun for me.


Almost(definitely) cried over a right hand, would watch again.

Parasyte: The Maxim is basically if Devilman Crybaby had been done right lol. This sci-fi/horror/action anime is one of the best made by studio Madhouse, and I actually like it more than their previous thriller Death Note. I don't have much time to re-watch anime series (mostly because I'd rather watch a new show) but I'm glad I revisited this one from 2015, which totally held up! Sure, I knew what was coming, but I'd still get excited on my 2nd viewing whenever the kickass music was about to start up. *Because* I knew what was coming, I could turn up the volume right beforethe beat dropped and, man, it was great.


What could've been a simple monster-of-the-week series evolved (hey, appropriate!) into something so much more, guys. Sure, Parasytes are killing people, but they're only doing so in order to survive. As the show points out, it's not so different from us humans killing and eating animals lower on the food chain in order to live. What's more, the show also depicts several moments of human cruelty and destruction, begging the eternal question of "Who are the real monsters here?" We also see some sympathetic portrayals of Parasytes, such as the woman Tamura Reiko who attempted to have a human baby and blend into human society.


What this show does best (as in 10/10) is its character development. We see some big changes in not just our everyman protagonist Shinichi, but also his hand Parasyte Migi! This was what I loved most about the show, how the two of them developed in different directions and became more like each other. After further exposure to Migi (and having his cells mixed with the Parasyte's) Shinichi becomes more cold and detached, less human. He even at one point throws out a dead dog in the garbage can, saying "It's just a dog shaped lump of meat now," something no human would say. Migi, on the other hand, starts out as a cynical self-serving alien, but over time grows more sympathetic towards humans. We see how his friendship with Shinichi has changed him, to the point where he even asks someone to try to understand how *Shinichi* feels, and he's even willing to put his own life on the line to rescue Shinichi?! It's wonderful. I was honestly hoping we'd get a similar relationship between Akira and Amon in Devilman Crybaby, but that's neither here nor there.


The animation is a perfect 10/10, the way the Parasytes glisten and shine when they morph and battle, it's just astounding. The dubstep soundtrack, while off-putting to some, fits perfectly in every scene it's used in. This 10/10 soundtrack is one I listen to all the time on its own, but I also can't separate it from the anime in my mind. It's essential! I also want to mention the excellent sound design in the show, the sound effects, right down to the eerie static-y voices the Parasytes use. So much attention to detail was put in this anime and that's why it's one of my all time favorites.


There were so many epic moments in this series, too many to count! Again the dubstep kicks in at key moments, transforming a simple scene where say Shinichi saves a kitten from being abused to something beyond epic. My favorite fight scene is when Shinichi must confront the Parasyte in the body of *spoilers* his mother. The action, the music, the emotion in this scene is so damn raw and perfect, I just love it. Another favorite moment is when Migi reappears during a battle, interrupting the frantic dubstep music with a simple "Yo," which had me laughing my ass off.


I have a few minor nitpicks of course. For one, the sound effect for Migi stretching sounds *a lot* like someone passing gas, and that would actually throw me off for a second in an otherwise tense action scene. I also thought for a horror anime, this actually wasn't that scary. To be fair, very few anime have actually scared me in the past. Still, Parasyte's a legendary 10/10. I hope the success of this show leads to more and more older manga being adapted to anime.

I read the manga months before the anime went out. I was glad when I found out that it got an anime adaptation but at the same time I wasn't because most adaptations don't follow the original book or do some enormous changes; this anime didn't let me down.
Story: 9
Humans have become species which are very harmful to the planet. To prevent their growing numbers, parasytes have come to earth, took control of people and after that they kill and eat them too. I don't really understand why but most of them kill their own kind as well (maybe they fight because of food, Idk).This parasyte wasn't able to invade the brain of Shinichi, the main protagonist, but instead grew on his right arm. Not being able to control Shinichi, the two must have extreme coordination when other parasytes try to kill them. Shinichi now having to live as half human and half parasyte is the most interesting thing to see in Kiseijuu aside from the fights and understanding Tamiya Ryouko, atleast for me.

The studio (Madhouse not sure) did an excellent job adapting the original book. Followed the manga and had a great pace.


Art: 8.5

The art has really improved. I didn't appreciate the manga's art but in the anime, I loved it. The fights are terrific, but sometimes the MC not doing a thing, the spotlight is only on Migi. (Although, I don't think I should be complaining about that in art section, my bad) For me, it is really cool, seeing how fast they fight that you won't know who's attacking or defending.

The character design changed in a better way. Shinichi's appearance before the "transformation", having eyeglasses and that hairstyle made him look quieter and more of 'intelligent' type (I prefer him that than the transformation and than how it was in the manga, maybe I'm just in fangirl mode lololol); the main female, murano and a supporting female, Kana, had a better design which made them look cuter and younger. Her personality plus this drastic char design change of Kana even made her more popular than Murano.


Sound: 9

The voice actors did a not outstanding but not terrible performance. I don't have much to say about that. There are only 2 things which left me an impression, how Tamura Ryouko laughed and migi's voice actress, yep actress: Aya Hirano. Maybe it's only me (well ^^") but I wouldn't have guessed that migi has even a female voice actress.

I don't like the op and ed to 'Dat' level but they aren't bad either.

Now the themes. They're fantastic heh. I'll give you a brief description, more like opinion, of my 2 favorites. 1- Next to you, this theme is a not so fast melody and has a melancholic and sad feeling. It's like someone's saying 'I know it's sad and tragic but you have to accept, fight and move on, because that's life'. 2- Migi's theme. A melody of someone full of curiosity wanting to define the mystery of the world.


Character: 9

Migi's and MC's relationship is really interesting. Starting from a doubtful one to faithful friendship. Shinichi accepted migi because of their experiences and hardships and vice versa. Migi became shinichi's best friend that he was thankful to not be able to control his brain. I like Migi because he isn't the typical parasyte that only wants to kill, he is always curious and fights using not only his powers but his intelligence as well.

Tamara reiko or Ryouko is like migi and that's why I like her too. Her character has a strong impact. Further description of her may make me write big spoilers.

Murano the female lead. She doesn't mean much to the story but well. When she said, 'you are Shinichi, aren't you?' and migi was already there, it made me 'woah hmmm, interesting'. Now stop saying that like 4 times in an episode, it was pretty annoying. I regret not counting how times she said that.

Enjoyment: 9 

I loved this anime for the positive things I wrote above about the various sections. Migi and Tamura made it more interesting. The moral about the the relation of human and the earth, and what the mc and the last antagonist spoke about made me open my eyes, because it is applied to real life too.

Parasyte -the maxim- spoiler free. 
First lets talk about the things I didn't like about Parasyte.
.....................................................................
Now that that's covered.
"Parasytes" invade Earth, taking over the brains of human hosts by entering through their ears or noses. One Parasyte attempts to crawl into Shinichi's ear while he sleeps, but fails since he is wearing headphones, and enters his body by burrowing into his arm instead, taking over his right hand. Because Shinichi was able to prevent it from traveling further up into his brain, both beings retain their separate consciousness. As the duo encounter other Parasytes, they capitalize on their strange situation and gradually form a strongbond, working together to survive. This gives them an edge in battling other Parasytes, who frequently attack the pair upon realization that Shinichi's human brain is still intact. Shinichi feels compelled to fight other Parasytes, who devour humans as food.\n\n
I love the writing and the direction of this story as it unfolds. The underlying themes of humans are toxic and are pollution etc. are common talk these days, so it was no surprise to hear such philosophy, but then I remember that this story was written in the early 90's, and I feel a bit more respect for it's message. Things are slow and take a nice steady pace. I enjoyed the tense situations and battles the way the were believably (within reason) handled by the characters. The fighting wasn't all super hero crazy like some other generic battle shounen I know, but still exciting. The melodrama is a little potent but it never felt really forced, and had some great moments built up with suspense that genuinely made me care what had happened. There are places I feel that could have been stronger, and left a little bit of detail uncovered, not really any loose ends, but a vague closure. But nothing that I feel was poor. \n\n
Shinichi feels more real then other certain MC's with the pacing and progression of his character. His reaction to situations are what you would expect from someone in his shoes, and his growth is very justified unlike some other anime where the hero becomes the savior because, well a hero is needed so they make it convenient.  The supporting cast is kinda shallow, but they are not really necessary to develop and are given enough attention to be relevant to the story's advancement, but are not forced into the scenario. Like Murano, who is there to serve as a reminder that Shinichi is changing. And Kana, who is needed to accelerate Shinichi's resolve. \n\n
I love the dubstep BGM used throughout the show as well as the OP, ED. The art desig, it looks great and animation is pretty solid during it's action. All and all, I loved this show.\n
Definitely recommend a watch.

This show is thrilling and extremely thought provoking. If you are interested in ethics, philosophy, biology, and/or sci-fi, this one's for you--- you just have to put up with a few shortcomings. The show does falls prey to these tropes: 1) completely unnecessary gore and massacre like in Deadman Wonderland 2) the main character's overdone obsession with human values (like in Tokyo Ghoul), and 3) Like in many parasite stories, there's only a rather vague explanation of the parasites' existence. But other than those holes, it's spot-on. Great writing, original story, good characters for the most part, decent art style, great music, and EXCELLENT fleshingout of all the what-ifs of a world where humans are preyed upon by another species. This show makes Tokyo Ghoul look like some 12-year-old's attempt at horror. Seriously, watch it.

I usually don't leave reviews, but my god, I couldn't let this go without one. This anime had a good concept to work with, and it's completely ruined by poor character development and cheesy dialogue.
Story (5/10):
The first initial episodes were great, as it set up Shinichi's newfound conflict and the curious musings of parasyte Reiko Tamura. Her mysterious interest in Shinichi, combined with his gradual transformations, draws you in as a viewer. Once her story arc ceases, however, it becomes the mediocre story of a boy getting chased by an alien. The story also leaves several loose ends unresolved, such as Kana's ability to senseparasytes, the investigator's suspicion of Shinichi, the group of parasytes enraged by MIgi's failed inhabitation of his brain, Reiko's baby . . . it's as if they wanted to add complexity to the story but fell short by leaving these subplots unfinished.


Character Development (2/10): 

Shinichi's character is not the brooding, deep character in existential crisis that some may have you believe. His internal and external dialogue are so forced to make him appear complex, that it feels as if you are being hit over the head with a hammer by the writers. His love triangle counterparts (Murano and Kana) lack any depth aside from fawning over him and giving the series a subplot. Reiko is the only mildly interesting character due to her evolution into becoming human-like and questioning her purpose as a parasyte. 


Art (8/10):

There is nothing wrong with the art in this series. It's not bad and is quite decent.


Sound (5/10):

Anytime Shinichi launched into a droning monologue about the existence of mankind, this terribly sappy theme music began to play and ruined any hope of me taking his words seriously. 


Overall (6/10):

Don't waste your time trying to finish Parasyte. It fails to achieve the level of hype it created in shallow character development, unfinished subplots, poor dialogue, and an unsuccessful attempt at exploring the niche of mankind.

NO SPOILERS
Story(8) I think Kiseijuu has a good story, a bit too simple sometimes(some events are too predictables). Despite this, from the beginning to the ending, I really enjoyed this anime. There is a simple philosophical thought all along the episodes but it led us to think about it very deeply.
Art(8) The line is clean like the colors, the animation is fluid. The negative point is the some battles scenes where the animation is a bit simplified but it won't really affect your enjoyment.
Sound(7) I liked the opening, the ending and "Next to you" but I don't really appreciate the dubsteps musics which are inKiseijuu. I fancy it doesn't fit with the atmosphere.\n\n
Character(8) It's pleasant to see the evolution of Migi and Izumi nevertheless, some characters aren't enough developed in my mind.\n\n
Enjoyment and Overall(9) Kiseijuu is a very good experience, very enjoyable where we rapidly get into a real thinking despite the little defects. I recommend it!

Parasyte was a good anime, the changes in Shinichi was huge when he got stabbed in the heart which made him almost emotionless. The fights between a parasyte and him was good too. What made me sadden was Kana, I think she deserve to be with Shinichi, Why i preferred Kana and Satomi was that Kana was kind of unique to be hearing wavelength which only a parasyte could, that was one special trait she had, while satomi was just one of your typical ordinary high school girl, being shy yeah. I don't hate her though, I just preferred kana. 
Kana was quite obsessed withShinichi, as far as plucking his hair and curl it to represent a ring and put it into the ring finger. And dreaming too. Kana first met shinichi when he got bullied by Kana and her gang. Kana told them to stop bullying and wanted to help him up, but sensing his right hand was weird, which made Kana curious and all the romance and stuff came up as kana became a "stalker".


The interesting part was when Shinichi became badass, after reviving from death by Migi. As shinichi became kind of strong, having part of some power from Migi, Migi really helped Shinichi a lot, but after gaining some of Migi's power they co -operate and defeated Parasytes.


Migi was a cute character, the voice was cute, what I like about Migi was that he was quite strong, protecting shinichi, and through out all he has experienced with Shinichi, they kind of became friend, and Migi seems a bit more understanding Humans and more of having compassion.


The story itself was okay, the plot was okay too as we see changes in Shinichi, Art was good, Sound was Amazing, especially Migi. Character development was kind of good as we could see changes. Enjoyment was definetely Fantsastic, I enjoyed a lot. Overall it was nice to see the anime.


Now to the ending of Parasyte, it was kind of confusing because the parasyte was gone and i was wondering where did they went. Migi disappeared, I would miss him, as Satomi and Shinichi live happy ever after, after some epic event happening. Where did migi went too, I meant he was in Shinichi body, its not like he would go anywhere else. Will miss migi. :( Kana too.

This is one of my favourite animes I've watched.
If you want Gore, action, excitement, tension and a bit of romance on the side; this could be the show for you.
I love this show as this show keeps you always on the edge of your seat, it sickens me with gore (which I love), surprises me with plot twists and doesn't dwindle on scenario or event for too long.
The main theme of the over populated earth retaliating against the human race by decreasing the population, is still done rather uniquely.
The main character is all about getting stronger but starts to lose his fears, faiths, beliefs, hishuman side. and in which how it effects those around him.\n
I love how they encorporated dubstep kind of music in the soundtrack at intense moments which is awesome. Moments where the characters actions are so stupid I laugh out loud happen often.\n
although there is a dead spot at one point, it resolves itself pretty fast. \n
overall great and you should give it a try although I know its likely you may not like it as much as me if you don't like plot holes.

Beautifully orchestrated.
The show shares with you the possible reality of the introduction of an invasive virus, or parasite. The show dances around the topic of life just enough to grab the attention of people with several different views on the subject before coming to a conclusion that some of you will find either deeply philosophical or simply common sense.
The first couple episodes are a bit stretched as the show tries to fit in the results this new threat poses to humanity. But by the third episode and so on, well, let's just say you better not have work or school in the morning. This wasa great anime to wait for it's completion for a full marathon.\n\n
My only complaint is that they should have put far more effort into the action scenes. Sure, they were still pretty epic for the style the director seemed to be going for, but the Dragon Ball Z, too fast to see, fighting style isn't as fun as it was back when I was a kid.\n\n
As a sidenote: About the soundtrack, I hate dubstep, vehemently so, but this anime used it so beautifully that I couldn't complain in the slightest. An intense scene crops up, the intensity reaches a climax, and then the climax is extended when Skrillex drops the bass. The blood starts pumping and shiver runs down my spine as I realize s*** just got real.

*NO SPOILERS*
[Story 9/10]
The story is great. Starts off kinda confusing, but easily catchy. The story continues as good as it starts and there are no boring episodes like other anime. In every episode the story is fluid and enjoyable. 
[Art 7/10]
The art lacks colors. But I can't count it as a bad thing because the intention of the creator was to create characters with more realistic features.  
[Sound 9/10]
The sound is beautiful. Starting from simple sound effects to the opening and ending, they're so beautifully composed you can't stop listening to them. They are really catchy. I give it a 9 mostly for theopening, which is my all-time favorite anime opening.\n\n
[Character 9/10]\n
The characters are even greater than the Sound. Main character, Shinichi, is one of the coolest anime characters I've ever seen. Every character adds his/her part on the story, each one of them plays a role in the main story, and interaction with the protagonist feels so natural and un-forced. The connection between the protagonist and the other characters is so good, you'll really end up asking for more after every episode ends.\n\n
[Enjoyment 8/10]\n
It's easily one of the most enjoyable anime I've ever seen. Every episode has its new features and new things added to the story. Everything is explained or shown so well, it's simply enjoyable. The main reason I didn't give Enjoyment a 9/10 is because some people might not enjoy the gore in it. The scenes are pretty graphic, but trust me, you have to give it a try!\n\n
[Overall 9/10]\n
A complete anime.\n
A unique anime combining elements like Action, Sci-fi, Horror, Psychological, Drama and seinen. All elements work so well with each other, a simple masterpiece.\n
It has simply accomplished everything it has aimed for, doing way more, adding even elements like Philosophical, romance and much more.\n
I think it's a MUST WATCH even for non-anime fans.\n\n

The anime is good. It does not deal with matters as deep as I imagined.
Sometimes it also becomes inconvenient when, I a moment of tension, out of nowhere appears a romantic scene (or that it should be as such).
The anime fights get tedious as the characters stand still and toss the tentacles forward.
The anime brings a good reflection on what our role in the world is and what we are. An important reflection that we have all thought about some day but we never go deep.
I do not have much to comment on the sound of the anime.
As for the animation, it's not so beautifulfor a 2014 anime.

I held out for so long on expressing my thoughts about this show. I figured, "Hey, maybe there was some underlying meaning in it all along," so I kept that at the back of my head and tried to think about Parasyte as a thought-provoking anime about human behavior and the threats of survival—
Which in my pure and honest belief, themes that aren't that strong to even save a crippling plot progression for the second half.
It may have been a few months since I watched Parasyte, but oh boy, do I remember distinctly how I felt like everything became a waste of time when Ifinished watching it.


Let's go straight ahead with the plot and execution. Shinichi Izumi is one of the victims of the silent invasion of extraterrestrial parasitic beings called Parasytes (may be, may be not, but for the sake of this review let's assume they're called such). However, he manages to prevent the complete invasion of the Parasyte inside him and traps the alien inside his right hand. The being turns out to have eaten his right hand and replaced it, and together they learn to co-exist as a team in order to survive against other hosts of the same race which varies on either neutrality or hostility.


Pretty simple for an entry in the science fiction. However, what Parasyte suffers from is not the cliché premise nor the straightforward outline—it's the fact that it's not a good show.


Despite a simple Point A to Point B storyline, the show never really knows what's it supposed to be—which I would like to call the Sword Art Online syndrome. It has romance, it has angst, it has sex jokes, it has blood, it has politics, it has ethics—but how the fuck do you cram that within 24 episodes and not look like a mess?


Well, it's not exactly the problem. The problem is Parasyte has terrible balancing of these genres. You have similar shows of roughly the same length like Evangelion that may be debatable on its plot progression and themes, but still pulls off the same tone all throughout. It had comedy, it had seriousness—but it never feels so overpowering and the show knows when it should stop.


Granted, that the show actually gets more serious in the later episodes of the series, with certain characters getting entangled in Shinichi's mess and the grief of maintaining a romantic relationship because of intergalactic affairs, but here comes the underlying problem of getting nowhere—not the genres this time, but the plot.


I did not understand what the hell was going on in the last couple of episodes. Everything had poorly-paced narratives, and not enough explanations were given on why they were doing this and why they were doing that. I wish I can elaborate more, but the more I tried to wrap my head around it, it fucking rips into pieces. The show starts off as a psychological sci-fi shounen-like first half, and the next episodes were a goddamn political and morally questioning thriller—which, mind you, should definitely be the direction it was taking, but there was no absolute reason why these situations are being thrown around suddenly!


I'm sure I've repeated myself in different phrases, but the pacing in this show is terrible, and makes me wonder how much content Madhouse had to cut off from the manga.


What's the next thing to dislike about Parasyte? Its poorly-written characters.


For the love of God do I not understand Shinichi's character development. He starts off as a wimp, then after [the thing which must not be spoiled] he turns into a badass with a nice hairdo. Then, after another shift in the final arc of the story, he's suddenly reverted to this wimping coward who just realized how he's scared for his life? Like no shit! And you may claim that the situations he's in are enough to make someone regress into cowardice, but the point stands that the bad pacing of this show ruins any semblance of notable character development.


Migi was okay, but I didn't feel anything special about him as much as he feels for humans. Murano, aside from being voiced by KanaHana, has nothing to go for as the main girl. And Kana, aside from being voiced by Sawashiro, has nothing to go for at all. I mean, why do people like this character? Just because she's some clingy bitch who can't even listen? She's just as poorly written as much as Murano is. The only character I have at least a little bit empathy for was Ryouko, and that's not saying much, considering how little her involvement was in Shinichi's arc aside from discussing philosophy and handing over a baby.


A lot of the praise to the show goes from its animation studio Madhouse, a long-standing behemoth of consistent quality and a role model for good production values—and I couldn't agree more. For Parasyte, however...


It's not to say that Parasyte had bad animation, per se, but I didn't feel as much sakuga as I expected. To top it off, there isn't enough gore as I felt it should have, coming from a show that has aliens preying on humans. I guess it's the thing with the show feeling more like a shounen than a seinen—which were my expectations. And the fight scenes were honestly boring—I felt more hyped watching JoJo fights where it's mostly oraoraoras.


If there's one thing I will always remember about Parasyte that was great, its the wonderfully animated OP that brings me goosebumps every time I hear it that also blends greatly with its song. The ED is a calming song after a long hard day at alien work and suits Shinichi's character nicely. The rest of the soundtrack—forgettable. I'd be fine with the dubstep if they didn't put it in every goddamn insert.


Was Parasyte deep, though? In some ways, I think it is. However, these themes are not well-explored and while the show would have been a good metaphor for racism and other heinous human acts, its execution really undersells its message.


I didn't hate Parasyte, but I feel like its writing is an insult to aspiring writers like me, who value pacing as an importance out of all things, and it strikes the heart how something like this is highly rated on MAL. People like Parasyte for the wrong reasons, because it's supposedly an "edgy" show for the cool kids. Parasyte is likable because it explores these themes that can be likened to other exceptional sci-fi shows with depth—which should be valued more as opposed to this heaping pile of mess.


For what it is, Parasyte is a good entry-level anime. But it's not even the best in being one. There are better shows out there that are worth your time, with the same level of impressiveness and theme explorations that do not slip on its own pace.

Parasyte was very good, I can probably relate it to Tokyo Ghoul but I felt this was much better.
Much better in the sense that though similar in context but highly different in stimulation.
