To put in I’m simpler terms, Parasyte is like Tokyo Ghoul in the sense that yes, the MC is half-human half-parasyte and that these parasytes eat and ‘possess’ humans similar to Ghouls that feed on humans.
The parasytes too can feed on other nutrients but prefer humans as food similar to ghouls.
The MC of Parasyte is a beast, he kills the enemy parasytes like a beast and faces off with tough opponents because ofthe new ‘power’ he developed.


BUT.


Parasyte has certain aspects that are different... There are parasytes that have the sole instinct to survive and will do anything in their power to Ensure survival, including killing their kind if they felt threatened.


There are also those that are highly intelligent, they want to know about humans and want to find out their “purpose” that is what captivated me about this anime, because of that MAJOR PLOT TWIST at the last few episodes, my perspective of the anime being a generic story of man eating monsters and an OP MC has changed. 


One of the parasyte(not the MC) developed human emotions contrary to the whole ‘Parasyte beliefs’


Therefore it is definitely worth spending your time on.

GUYS THIS IS REALLY AMAZING!!!!!!!!!!!Warning this may contain some minor spoilers. First of all I have to admit that the writer was fully aware of parasites. Indeed parasites are much more developed than bacteria, viruses etc. In fact they use us as hosts and can do incredible things. One parasite (i don't remember the name now, anyway) causes the host to eat sand (yeah indeed!!!) so that more parasites of his kind will accommodate the host. Some parasites do not appear in the circulation of the host in the morning and appear in the circulation in the night when the host most likely is sleeping( as a defence mechanism) that's why doctors must know precisely the time of the appearance of the parasite, in order to detect them in blood samples. Apart from that there is a neurological syndrome called alien hand, in which your right hand is not under your control and you don't understand it when it is moving. Maybe the writer was inspired by these two facts. Anyway let's get to the plot. The plot is really amazing cause they paid attention even to the slightest details. For example when the parasite tried to enter the protagonist's hand at first it tried to move forward subcutaneously and when there was something on the way (the earings with which the protagonist tied his hand) it tried to move throught the blood flow. However the earings were tied so tight that also the blood flow was cut and the parasite couldn't move forward in order to take over the brain. Therefore it was stuck in his hand. Apart from that the plot is really deep. An example: How can you be sure that the way you feel is genetically determined? For example how can you be so sure that when you were 5 years old, your parents were lovey doveys, so this was a very strong stimulus that made you subconsciously imitate this way of behaving and as a result you are very romantic? It is a major issue between psychosociologists whether the way we feel is genetically determined or it is affected by our environment. That's why a parasite, although at first was genetically programmed to have no feelings at all, in the end gained some maternal feelings! And how can you be so sure that maternal love and maternal sacrifice isn't just a genetic programmed feeling in order to maintain our species? But above all the story unravels the human nature. It shows that in fact we are a species that are the ultimate predators. We have developed compassion for other humans as a way to prioritize human life and multiply our species.Guys it really worths watching!

【 The following is a review of : Kiseijuu and Kiseijuu: Sei no Kakuritsu 】
I’m going to cover both the anime and the manga of Parasyte in this review. So, pretty much, Kiseijuu vs. Kiseijuu: Sei no Kakuritsu. To preface, Hitoshi Iwaaki is one of the most prolific names in Japanese horror comics, Parasyte being his most referenced and revered work. His historical work, Historie, has a lot of fans as well but not nearly as many followers as the people who follow his ever trending, cult classic Parasyte. 
	• Iwaaki’s art style is very distinctive and he’s even made cameos in famous short storycompilations like Neo Devilman, a love letter to Go Nagai more or less with many artists interpretations, though with all of the erotic shorts, I think it should be considered a doujinshi. There was even a compilation collection, like Devilman, for Parasyte, called Neo Parasyte.


	• Since Devilman went on to influence Berserk’s Kentarou Miura and Evangelion’s Hideaki Anno, and for Iwaaki you can plainly see Parasyte’s effect on the anime horror genre, he’s even had a tremendous influence on the works of  Junji Ito though Ito was mostly, verbatim, influenced by Kazuo Umezu, I think that it speaks volumes if they can both inspire so many people that there’s anthology short story collection for both of them.


	• You get my point, Parasyte is a very important manga! To be frank, I thought the manga was good and the anime was garbage. I may be biased, since I had read the manga years before the anime aired and I know many people love the animated version, but I, for one, couldn’t get behind it. The animation was inconsistent, if you watch the trailer for the first episode and then compare the animation quality, it’s obvious that they just used all of the well-animated scenes in the promotional material. 


	• The music was awful, save for the opening because Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas are my jams; there was tone-deaf dubstep playing at inappropriate moments. The comedic timing in the show is horrendous. I know it’s not meant to be a funny show, but the manga had relatively campy humor, like the penis hand and the parasite woman jogging with her top half effaced. 


	• The panel layout for the penis hand scene actually made it seem in good taste, where the anime version was clunky and weird. I thought the voice acting mostly sounded amateurish in the Japanese audio as well, other than Migi’s voice. I give a thumbs up to his voice actress. 


	• I didn’t like that Shinichi’s character was adapted in the anime to be a geek that becomes a badass, because is incredibly cliché, and it wasn’t a thing in the manga. When I first saw the character designs, I thought it might be okay, but the anime portrays him as an unlikable perverted loser rather than what he was in the manga: an average 80’s kid.


	• The series is chalk full of plot conveniences and stupidity, while the manga is shorter and so, these flaws are practically non-existent. The anime is not a faithful adaptation; there are many artistic liberties taken. The plot is very shaky and unfocused. I believe anything good about Kiseijuu that you want can be found in the manga. 


	• Overall, don’t watch the anime adaptation. I had the same kind of clairvoyance at the ending of the Kiseijuu manga that I did when I read a good novel, like with The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao written by Junot Diaz, not quite the heightened emotional reaction I got from Nabokov’s Lolita, but a feeling that had me walking outside and the sky seeming more vibrant than usual because of my enlightenment from reading something spectacular. Like aーI’m satisfied being a human feeling.


	• I don’t know if any of you can relate to that, but please read the manga instead of watching the anime, so you can actually contract some kind of feeling from an otherwise empty waste of garbage. Parasyte: The Maxim is one of the worst animated adaptations, if not the worst, in anime history. I give Kiseijuu: the manga a 8/10 and the anime a 2/10.

Kiseijuu: Sei no Kakuritsu really has something special to it... It's one of these animes in which I was initially looking for horror, but stayed for the plot and beautiful art style. This anime has a great aftertaste - it lifts you up and makes you think. 
Even though I found quite a few things to nitpick, overall I really enjoyed the story. This anime has something I haven't observed before - it can shift the mood in a matter of seconds, but do it so effortlessly that it feels natural. One moment you'll have adrenaline rushing through your body, but the other - eyeswet from tears. Despite what turns the plot would take, it felt natural, nothing seemed forced just ''for the sake of story''. And, honestly, that intro just kept me going. It fits the anime (and my music taste) perfectly.\n\n
I don't really want to go much in details, but if you're somebody who is looking for a good bit of action-packed horror that goes along with a non-linear drama-filled storyline, this anime is a good place to start.

Exists as an allegory for the toxicity of humanity to Earth, and focuses on the hypocrisy and lack of logical consistency of anthropocentrism, most specifically in regard to treatment of animals and general exploitation/pollution of the environment. The writer very clearly wanted to design a shonen masque around this central idea, and created 3-4 major plots points to continue engaging the viewer so they could eventually express their ideas. Aside from these few points, most of the show exists either in a lull, or in a state where the main character has no influence or part of the events taking place. Even when these majorpoints are hit, the author could have had better understanding and clarity when expanding his thesis and examining human society. 


The idea of altruism deconstructs most of the characters "motives", and is only barely touched on at the very end of the show. Feels like something they found out or finally thought about 15 episodes in when they touch on it, realized their mistake, and just pushed the story into a place where altruism no longer would be a character motive.


Many character lines are simply repeated over and over again, as if the writer had no understanding or willingness to further flesh out any of the supporting characters beyond what bare minimum role they had to play. The few main characters though do develop well and transition with decent seamlessness. Some main character lines are awkward or misplaced, but all in all pretty consistent.


Sound was fine. Some of the random dubstep tracks distracted from the medium, and some of the battle foley certainly were not selected or produced correctly. Animation was Madhouse (great). Enjoyable enough to be recommended.
